unnormalised: Reserve Bank of India (RBI) issues directives regularly regarding cash deposit and withdrawal rules in banks. These regulations primarily aim to curb money laundering and maintain transparency in financial transactions. Depositing Rs. 50,000 or more in a single day necessitates the submission of your PAN card as per the IT Act, 1961. Failure to provide PAN may lead to the rejection of the deposit.
normalised: Reserve Bank of India (R-B-I) issues directives regularly regarding cash deposit and withdrawal rules in banks. These regulations primarily aim to curb money laundering and maintain transparency in financial transactions. Depositing rupee fifty thousand or more in a single day necessitates the submission of your P-A-N card as per the I-T Act, one thousand nine hundred and sixty one. Failure to provide P-A-N may lead to the rejection of the deposit.

unnormalised: For cash withdrawals exceeding Rs. 2 lakh in a single day, banks often require prior intimation. This step is in place to ensure sufficient cash availability and to monitor large transactions closely. Banks like SBI, HDFC Bank, and ICICI Bank adhere strictly to these guidelines. Note that these rules apply to all banking customers, whether they hold savings accounts, current accounts, or any other type of deposit account.
normalised: For cash withdrawals exceeding rupee two lakh in a single day, banks often require prior intimation. This step is in place to ensure sufficient cash availability and to monitor large transactions closely. Banks like S-B-I, H-D-F-C Bank, and I-C-I-C-I Bank adhere strictly to these guidelines. Note that these rules apply to all banking customers, whether they hold savings accounts, current accounts, or any other type of deposit account.

unnormalised: Senior citizens availing schemes like Senior Citizen Savings Scheme (SCSS) also need to abide by these rules when depositing or withdrawing amounts. For example, if a senior citizen deposits Rs. 1.5 lakh into their SCSS account, they must provide their PAN details. Similarly, if they withdraw over Rs. 200000 at once, the bank might ask for advance notice.
normalised: Senior citizens availing schemes like Senior Citizen Savings Scheme (S-C-S-S) also need to abide by these rules when depositing or withdrawing amounts. For example, if a senior citizen deposits rupee one point five lakh into their S-C-S-S account, they must provide their P-A-N details. Similarly, if they withdraw over rupee two lakh at once, the bank might ask for advance notice.

unnormalised: Small businesses and traders who frequently deal with cash transactions should be particularly aware of these RBI norms. Regular transactions involving amounts above Rs. 1 lakh may trigger scrutiny from the Income Tax Department if not properly documented. Digital payment methods like UPI and NEFT are encouraged to reduce cash handling.
normalised: Small businesses and traders who frequently deal with cash transactions should be particularly aware of these R-B-I norms. Regular transactions involving amounts above rupee one lakh may trigger scrutiny from the Income Tax Department if not properly documented. Digital payment methods like U-P-I and N-E-F-T are encouraged to reduce cash handling.

unnormalised: The penalty for non-compliance can range from a fine of Rs. 10,000 to potentially facing income tax investigations. It's also worth knowing that transactions reported under suspicion, even if below the threshold, can prompt inquiries. Remember, these rules are not meant to hinder legitimate banking activities but to safeguard the financial system.

unnormalised: Lastly, always keep your KYC details updated with your bank. An incomplete or outdated KYC can result in transaction restrictions. Banks often send reminders for KYC updates, and failure to respond can lead to account freezing. Therefore, stay informed about the latest banking regulations from the RBI to avoid any inconvenience.
